Quantum mechanics is a theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of phenomena. However, it is not a complete theory, and there are many questions that it cannot answer. One of the most fundamental of these is the issue of free will. This paper addresses this question by showing that the mathematical structure of quantum mechanics can be modified in a very simple way so as to make it possible to predict the outcome of a coin toss with certainty.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian species. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan evolved from a free-living cnidarian and that the extreme degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus has been shown to antagonize the antiviral action of interferon (IFN) by blocking nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2. Here, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of importin/karyopherin. We demonstrate that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and binds to the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is required for nuclear import of importin/karyopherin. We further show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its antagonistic function. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be exploited by other viruses to evade IFN signaling. Our findings may also provide a target for the development of new antiviral strategies. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. Climate change will affect the productivity of major crops, including maize, the most important staple food crop for more than a billion people. We quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and yield variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most of the world. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of diverse species is a fundamental challenge of ecology. One of the most important challenges is to understand how species with similar ecological requirements coexist. This is particularly important in the context of human-dominated landscapes, where competition for resources can be intense. We show that the coexistence of seven species of large mammalian herbivores in a semiarid African savanna is linked to their dietary differences.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. This sink may be of major importance in the fate of the missing plastic debris.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is still a matter of debate. We present the first interstellar cosmic ray exposure ages of SiC grains. We find that the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This suggests that the grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains were probably irradiated by cosmic rays in the interstellar medium. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of SiC grains. They also provide constraints for the formation of presolar grains in general. This article is protected by copyright. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, and there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years. However, the global fleet is still expanding, and the effective CPUE of many countries is still below its 1950s value. The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. In the case of mammals, this ability is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, in which a mother nurses her offspring, is the most effective way to increase reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. VX-765 was able to reduce truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. VX-765 is well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to specific stimuli. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure, hemostasis, inflammation, and the contractility of the vascular smooth muscle cells. The endothelium is a highly complex system that is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other by a network of communication channels. The nature of this communication network has been poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The results reveal that the communication network is a small-world network, which is a highly efficient network design that is effective for both local and global communication. The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health event, with enormous data challenges. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages.

Potassium channels are a large family of ion channels that are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes. They are responsible for the generation of action potentials in neurons and muscle cells. They are also involved in the regulation of heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. An allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is constantly changing in response to the host’s diet and environment. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is thought to be important in the regulation of the immune system and the production of metabolites that are used by the host. The gut microbiome of herbivores is poorly characterized, and the potential of the microbiome to synthesize natural products has not been explored. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome of herbivores synthesize a variety of natural products. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important producers of natural products in the gut microbiome. This work provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The design of multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses. It is expected to inspire the design of multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses in various fields.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin content of red blood cells is determined by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental context-dependent manner. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in erythroid tissues and that it can affect the expression of hemoglobin genes. We show that IGF2BP1 can be used as a chronoregulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the overall survival of cancer patients remains poor. One of the major reasons for this poor outcome is the emergence of cancer drug resistance. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that the activation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, our findings suggest that targeting the mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. This strategy may be applicable to other forms of regulated necrosis, such as apoptosis. (Read more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in hypertension treatment. It also provides a potential target for the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension-induced heart failure. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds, but did halt the decline of early-seral–associated birds. However, the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, and the early-seral ecosystem area declined in two ecoregions. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is therefore a major challenge. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We show that our approach is successful in identifying compounds that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compound identified by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic. The compounds identified by us are promising candidates for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. This approach can be used to identify new antibiotics for other classes of antibiotics as well.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This work provides a new perspective on the design of deep convolutional neural networks. It is expected to be useful in many image-processing applications.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. The species flock is endemic to Lake Malawi, and the evolution of the species is thought to be driven by ecological opportunities created by the changing hydroclimate of the lake. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate from Lake Malawi. We show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the changing hydroclimate of the lake.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that this practice has important implications for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also highlights the need for more research on the effects of these devices on sleep and circadian rhythms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses. However, its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to the development of autoimmune diseases. We also show that CTLA-4 deletion affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. This may explain the variable outcomes of CTLA-4 deficiency in different autoimmune models. Our findings may also have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. The development of new vaccines and treatments is a long and expensive process. Therefore, it is important to develop methods that can rapidly identify new therapeutic candidates. Here, we demonstrate the utility of a deep learning approach in antibody engineering. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the binding affinity of an antibody against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our results highlight the potential of deep learning in antibody engineering and its application to the development of new therapeutic candidates against emerging variants. This approach can potentially be applied to other protein molecules.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits are transmitted from one generation to the next. The extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform determines AD risk by a factor of 12. APOE2 increases AD risk and APOE4 decreases it. APOE is also a potent regulator of astrocyte function. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may explain the increased AD risk associated with APOE4. These studies also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.08 g/cm3, which is 13.6 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed by the rapid solidification of the outer core, which is a liquid. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the solidification of the outer core. This mechanism provides a solution to the inner core nucleation paradox and opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results are expected to provide insights into the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well established, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in brain reactivity to methylphenidate. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers contributes to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. The findings also highlight the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also unique in the brain: Language areas are not specialized for language but rather for communication in general. This makes it difficult to study language in the brain. Here, we take advantage of recent advances in artificial intelligence to link models of language to models of the brain. We find that the most powerful models of language comprehension generalize across different datasets and tasks and predict neural activity near perfectly. Models’ neural fits and fits to behavioral performance are correlated with each other and with how well the models predict the next word in a sequence. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is that of instability. This paper shows that there are problems in scientific computing where there exist stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This paper also introduces a new class of stable NNs, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which are shown to be stable and converge fast. These results are expected to be useful in the development of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of the most prominent is the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This is supposedly a result of a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, the experiment’s critical design flaws went unnoticed at the time. They are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by the loss of tactile sensation and the development of characteristic lesions on the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucosa. The disease is highly stigmatizing and can be fatal if left untreated. The causative agent of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the disease is now treated with a combination of drugs. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a new leprosy pathogen, M. lepromatosis, and compared it with that of the well-characterized M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are still closely related and have not undergone extensive evolutionary divergence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two concepts that are most affected by the interaction between a system and its environment. Therefore, they are the two concepts that are most relevant to the study of isolated systems. However, the study of entanglement in isolated systems is extremely challenging. We show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a regime that is accessible to the study of interacting systems. This result is a milestone in the study of entanglement in isolated systems.

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease that has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only currently available vaccine against COVID-19, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This vaccine is not suitable for mass vaccination programs. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. This vaccine is highly attenuated in vivo and protects hamsters from infection with the wild-type virus. The vaccine is also cost-effective and can be manufactured in large quantities. These properties make it suitable for mass vaccination programs.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) was characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics. The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodents and fleas being the most common hypotheses. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the spread of infectious diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is rarely studied. Here, we show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a rationale for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is controlled by proteins that bind and unbind to actin filaments. One of these proteins is cofilin, which is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility. However, the mechanism by which cofilin disassembles actin filaments is not well understood. Here, we show that cofilin can induce torque on actin filaments, which enhances the rate of severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to disassemble highly connected actin filaments in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of cofilin in cell motility. They also suggest a way to control the disassembly of highly connected filament networks, which is important in many applications, including tissue engineering.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain reactivity to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. The results also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is home to a unique language, culture, and genetic heritage. We present a high-resolution view of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The genetic structure of the population is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a unique view of the history of Madagascar and its people. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence for it in the real world is controversial. Here, we show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others in a large real-world social network. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others in a large real-world social network. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networking services and for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networking services and for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis. The presence of mRNA modifications can alter the translation of these mRNAs. Here, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ moieties in mRNA sequences and that the presence of Ψ can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products. These findings have implications for the translation of mRNAs in cells and could be important for understanding the function of Ψ in the context of mRNA translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health, and healthier lifestyles. These associations are robust over a 4-y period and are not driven by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining characteristic of aquatic mammals. We use a model of energy intake and expenditure to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world. The virus responsible for the vast majority of these infections, human rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is thought to be due to a less efficient antiviral response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that the mouse airway cell is a useful model for studying the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus. We also show that the innate immune response of infected cells is a major determinant of the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the common cold virus’s ability to cause disease at cool temperatures. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to detect surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to attach to surfaces and to induce virulence and biofilm formation. The pili-mediated surface sensing system is a unique example of a mechanochemical system that measures the mechanical activity of pili and uses this information to regulate pili activity. This system is important for the pathogen’s ability to sense surfaces and to adapt to changing environments.

The use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing worldwide. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global risk of pesticide contamination of surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global pesticide contamination of surface waters.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the emergence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for the pandemic, has been a major public health event. The virus has been shown to be highly transmissible between humans, but the extent to which it can be transmitted between animals has not been well characterized. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that soluble Aβ species, rather than Aβ plaques, are the primary toxic amyloid species in neurons, and that these burden-bearing cells are responsible for initiating an inflammatory response within the brain. Our results suggest that intraneuronal Aβ accumulation may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a molecular basis for the development of AD and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for its use in economic purposes is, however, still unknown. We present evidence from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the use of chickens in economic purposes in the world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process. It is not a single event, but rather a series of steps. The steps are not independent of each other, but rather are connected. The steps are not random, but rather are guided by the structure of the protein. The steps are not the same for all proteins, but rather are different for different proteins. The steps are not the same for all proteins in all cells, but rather are different in different cells. The steps are not the same for all proteins in all organisms, but rather are different in different organisms. The steps are not the same for all proteins in all environments, but rather are different in different environments.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular response to such stress is often accompanied by the inactivation of the enzymes responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanisms of action are the depletion of lymphocytes and the induction of immunosuppression. We hypothesized that arginine, a key amino acid in the immune system, could be a target for the treatment of sepsis. We found that arginine administration was not effective in restoring immune function in sepsis. However, we found that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, was effective in restoring lymphocyte function and decreasing immunosuppression. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This approach could be used as a therapeutic strategy to treat sepsis in the future. The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the Earth system. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the Earth system. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state, and yet the system can change its critical state to a noncritical state by some external stimulus. The simplest example is a sandpile, where the stimulus is the addition of a grain of sand. The sandpile will then stop growing and will remain in a critical state. This is a very interesting phenomenon, but it is not easy to understand. We present a toy model, which is a tropical geometry model, and we show that it has SOC behavior.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new route to graphite via phonon instability. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

Cysteine-rich peptides are a diverse group of antimicrobial peptides that are expressed in plants and animals. They are known to exhibit antifungal activity. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the mode of action of these peptides against plant fungal pathogens are not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula, and demonstrate that it exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide binds to phosphoinositides and penetrates the fungal cell wall and membrane. These results provide insights into the structural basis of antifungal activity of this class of peptides. This work also paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during their posttesticular life history. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Platelet function is altered in the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of VWD mutations, explaining pathophysiology. This suggests that the single molecule data are not artifacts of the bulk phase. These results provide a mechanism for the effects of mutations in VWF. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with the human body, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database is available to the public and can be used to study the human virome in a variety of ways.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This technique will be a significant contribution to the field of ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is ∼15 °C, whereas the temperature inferred from protein data is ∼70 °C. Here, we show that the temperature inferred from protein data is consistent with isotopic data. This finding is significant because the protein data are independent of isotopic data and because the isotopic data are not subject to the same uncertainties as the protein data.

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. Malaria is a major cause of death worldwide, with the parasite exploiting the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host erythrocyte to facilitate invasion. This is the first time that we have been able to show that the parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host erythrocyte, suggesting that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a significant finding, with implications for the development of new antimalarial therapies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new route to graphite via phonon instability. Our findings are expected to be useful for diamond-based applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine design and therapy. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences and word lists is consistent with a model in which each word is merged into a phrase, and that this merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to build a hierarchy of nested phrases from the incoming language stream. This parser is consistent with the left-corner model of language proposed by linguists.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the function of redundant genes. It also provides a model for the regulation of redundant genes in the context of a signaling pathway. This work may be useful in the development of new therapeutics.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA). We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This technology could be used to deliver nitrogen in a controlled and targeted manner to the plant, which could improve the efficiency of nitrogen use and reduce the environmental impact of agriculture. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is losing forest at an accelerating rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider can detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. We show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.73 °C. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results highlight the importance of air pollution in the assessment of climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with over 300,000 deaths per week. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several promising candidates are in clinical trials. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. Here we report a strategy to reduce the cost of a subunit vaccine for COVID-19 by engineering the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein. The engineered RBD exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD used in current vaccines. This strategy may be applied to other vaccine candidates, and could lead to a more affordable vaccine for the global community. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in a variety of developmental processes. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs (DrALKs) are activated by secreted ALKALs (DrALKals). We further show that DrALKals are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish and Drosophila larvae. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKal signaling in neural crest development. This is the first report of a ligand–receptor interaction in the ALK family. Our findings may lead to a better understanding of the function of ALK/ALKal signaling in development and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-documented event. However, the evolutionary history of this progenitor is poorly understood. Here, we present 17 genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic was already present in Eurasia at this time, and that it spread rapidly across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in explaining men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can maximize SOC storage on grassland-derived Mollisols remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and applying manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not significantly increase SOC storage in perennial pastures. These results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial grasslands into agricultural systems to maximize SOC storage on Mollisols. This is particularly important given that the majority of SOC storage in the United States is on private lands. Our results also highlight the importance of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems, which are the dominant agricultural system in the United States. This study provides a framework for understanding the potential of soil health management practices to increase SOC storage in agricultural systems worldwide. This framework can be used to inform the development of agricultural policies that incentivize the adoption of soil health management practices.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing the threat of emerging viruses. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses can be used to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be essential for the global community to better understand and mitigate the threat of emerging viruses.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often an important factor in attracting pollinators. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this pigment in other plants.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. This is due to the lack of population-level genome data from this time. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 470 and 520 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals in our sample is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. However, the lack of laboratory capacity in resource-scarce settings impedes the detection of these pathogens. We demonstrate that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study highlights the importance of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. The RNA world hypothesis proposes that life on Earth evolved from an RNA-based primitive biochemistry. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the RNA-based origin of life. We show that RNA can be used to store and replicate genetic information. This work represents a major step toward understanding the origins of life on Earth and beyond.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the initial appearance of the neighborhood, the density of college-educated adults, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results provide a new way to study the physical dynamics of cities. They also suggest that physical improvements in neighborhoods are not random but are instead driven by factors that are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of the neighborhoods. This work provides a new perspective on the causes of urban change.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical patients is difficult. Tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathways, is effective in treating rheumatoid arthritis and other inflammatory diseases. In this study, we found that tocilizumab can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper homeostasis is essential for fungi, and the mechanisms for its acquisition and detoxification are well established. However, the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi has not been demonstrated. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding isocyanide in Aspergillus fumigatus, a human fungal pathogen. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster was identified and characterized, and the copper-binding properties of xanthocillin were demonstrated. The existence of the xanthocillin gene cluster in other filamentous fungi suggests a role for these natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This discovery may lead to the development of new antifungal agents. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2 (Alpha Particle X-Ray Spectrometer analysis). Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific and that these strategies can be used to forecast the future evolution of frost damage. Our findings can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and is unable to induce colitis in recipients, whereas the other subset transitions to a Th1-like phenotype and is required for colitis development. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis. Furthermore, our results suggest that the development of Th1 cells can be influenced by Th17 cells. This may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms of disease progression are not fully understood. We now report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This will accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new therapies. This method will also be useful for other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which infectious agents influence the composition of the vector microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We identify a protein encoded by the pathogen that alters the composition of the vector microbiota, which in turn influences the ability of the pathogen to colonize the vector. These data provide insights into the molecular mechanisms by which infectious agents influence the composition of the vector microbiota. This knowledge will be critical for the development of vector control strategies for infectious diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the origin and diversification of birds. The study of the early evolution of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group and provides insights into the origin and evolution of the modern avian tail.

The climate system is very complex, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the underlying processes. This paper shows that one of the most important processes is the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere as the climate warms. This increase in water vapor is a feedback that makes the climate warmer.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments. In some species, the absorption spectrum of pigments is modified by the presence of proteins that bind the pigments and change their color. This phenomenon is called color modification. In this study, we describe a mechanism of color modification in anurans (frogs and toads), which has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes tumor growth are poorly understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on messenger RNA. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α. ALKBH5 expression is required for hypoxia-induced enrichment of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in hypoxic tumors may contribute to the development of BCSCs, which are associated with poor prognosis. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium (IE) is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.
