The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry. The electronegativity and chemical hardness of an atom are two of the most important properties in this context. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and that this decrease is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the pseudo–noble-gas elements Ni, Pd, and Pt are electron acceptors, while the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) are electron donors, and the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) are electron donors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a first step toward the development of a pressure-dependent chemical model.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can affect the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a large effect on fire activity, and that these effects may offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions in driving future fire regimes, and the need to consider both climate and human drivers of fire in future projections.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a luminescent symbiont in a squid–vibrio mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provisioned only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting carbon and energy to increase the pH of the luminescent crypts. This work provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis dynamics and the potential for glycans to be used as a tool to manipulate the activities of specific microbes in the body. Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important in many domains. However, there is a need for methods to identify latent patterns in text data. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify gender biases in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The disease was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This study provides evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its spread across Eurasia. It also highlights the importance of climate change in the spread of the disease. Asteroids are a common and important component of the marine food web. However, in recent years, a number of species have experienced a dramatic decline in abundance. The cause of this decline is unknown, but we show here that the disease-induced mortality of asteroids is likely to be due to a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a marine invertebrate disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML patients remains poor. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is home to a unique language, culture, and genetic heritage. We present a high-resolution view of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The genetic structure of the population is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) and a 164-nucleotide RNA (denoted AzuR). We found that AzuC interacts with the membrane-associated aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, GlpD, and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also found that the RNA encoding AzuC interferes with the ability of the RNA and AzuC to repress cadA and galE. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate metabolism. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of variants-resistant neutralizing antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting index is robust to the biases and limitations of the original data, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our method can be used to improve the quality of crop monitoring systems in many countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this. Here we propose a mechanism that relies on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is simple, and it is sensitive to context and serial order. It is also sensitive to the history of the system, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of plastids and their evolution during the course of the evolution of eukaryotic life on Earth are among the most fundamental questions in biology. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key element in the study of these questions. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes under the influence of the transition from photosynthesis to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolution of plastid genes is shaped by a complex interplay between the loss of photosynthesis, the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle, and the evolution of the host–parasite interaction. This interplay is likely to have shaped the evolution of plastid genomes throughout the course of eukaryotic evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a first step towards quantifying the impact of climate change on the water security of cities. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major breakthrough in the field of materials science. However, the origin of these materials has been a mystery. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion. The age of the sample is known precisely because it contains a chemical element that was not present in the world before nuclear weapons were created. This discovery provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the creation of nuclear weapons.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The photosynthetic apparatus is composed of a number of pigments, which capture the solar radiation and transfer it to the reaction center. The pigments are modified tetrapyrroles, which are synthesized by a number of enzymes. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll pigments is a key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is characterized by the activation of microglia and astrocytes, which produce proinflammatory mediators. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a key kinase that is involved in neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes are cell-type–specific therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation in EAE. ASK1-targeting therapies may be a promising approach for the treatment of MS. This study provides insights into the roles of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that additional global warming will increase the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions, which will likely lead to more severe drought in California and elsewhere.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of ASD is so complicated that it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we identified a converging function of autism-risk genes in Drosophila. We found that the behavioral inflexibility of ASD-risk gene mutants was caused by the inability to forget. This finding suggests that the forgetting process is a common mechanism for ASD. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of ASD. It also provides a model system for studying the underlying mechanisms of ASD. (Show more)

This work is the first to report cross-national evidence on the prevalence of negativity biases in news content. It finds that, on average, news content is more negative in 17 countries than in 17 other countries. It also finds that, on average, individual differences in news responsiveness are large. These findings have implications for the study of news content, the study of human cognition and behavior, and the study of the news media.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, the molecular sensor of store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE), are responsible for this disorder. We also show that mutations in the pore-forming protein of SOCE, ORAI1, can also cause this disorder. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and suggest new therapeutic strategies for this disorder. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. These findings may provide a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways supporting cell growth is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway. Here we identify a scaffold that inhibits SHMT, and we use this scaffold to discover dual inhibitors of SHMT1/2. We show that these inhibitors are effective in cancer cells, but not in normal cells. We also show that one of the adverse effects of SHMT inhibition is defective glycine import into cancer cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of neuropathological subtypes. Here, we show that the proteins that are characteristic of each of these subtypes are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of the proteins in question, which are themselves supersaturated. We propose that this is the result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the neuropathology of ALS and suggests a mechanism for the development of the disease. (Read more)

The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the evolution of life on Earth. The earliest flowering plants are poorly understood, and the origin of aquatic angiosperms is poorly understood. The study presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Pyrenees of Spain in the late 19th century. The study of more than 1,000 specimens of Montsechia, including a detailed description of its anatomy, suggests that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that is sister to eudicots. Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We found that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Without the first cleavages, MERS viruses resisted conformational changes that are induced by cell receptors, and therefore were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This work provides insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may inform the development of MERS-CoV vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Read more)

The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population are a key driver of this problem. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40% and decreased the proportion of meat meals purchased by 15%. These results have important implications for the food system and for the health of the population. They suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a powerful tool for reducing the environmental impact of the food system and improving population health. This approach could be applied in other settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a rich source of information about the cell’s biology. Here we use a combination of methods to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the biology of the surfaceome in a variety of contexts.

The 2020 presidential election will be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. As a result, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand vote-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The mechanisms by which the virus causes disease and spreads rapidly are not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is formed through a unique sequence in ORF8, which is not present in SARS-CoV. These findings provide insight into the unique immune evasion and spread activities of SARS-CoV-2. This work also provides a foundation for the development of future vaccine and therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These results provide a molecular mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This mechanism may be useful for the development of new therapies for cerebral edema. The scientific method is based on the idea that we should test the strength of our hypotheses. In the past, this was done by conducting experiments and analyzing the results. Today, with the advent of big data, we have the potential to test our hypotheses with much larger datasets. However, this raises the question of how to properly assess the strength of the associations that we find. We describe a new approach to this problem that is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most important cell type in the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult, and the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from primary human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in vivo. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Recently, two physiological ligands for Alk and Ltk were discovered. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that the augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. Deficiency in augmentor ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the physiological function of Alk and Ltk and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a model system for studying the function of other orphan RTKs in vivo. This work may lead to the discovery of new therapeutic targets for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for T2D. Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is composed of eight segments of single-stranded RNA, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly regulated process, and the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. We show that this interaction is required for optimal viral replication and that it favors copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a key step in the packaging process and suggest that it might be a target for antiviral therapy. This interaction might also limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the formation of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a molecular basis for the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and athero-atherosclerosis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may provide a new therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the initial appearance of the neighborhood, the density of college-educated adults, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results suggest that urban planners and policymakers can use these methods to identify neighborhoods that are likely to experience physical improvements and to target resources to these neighborhoods. Our results also suggest that urban change is not a simple process of “invasion” or “tipping,” but rather a complex process that involves both the “invasion” and the “tipping” of attractive neighborhoods. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropod pests remain elusive. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests, and also sheds light on the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the host immune response is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise in viremia, the presence of an eclipse phase, and the rapid decline in viremia after treatment. We also provide estimates of the parameters of the model and of the effect of antiviral treatment. Our results provide a framework for understanding the disease and for guiding the design of future clinical trials. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of coral color and the bleaching of the coral tissue. The underlying causes of coral bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to understand the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that plays a central role in host–microbe interactions. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the interplay between tumors and the microbiome, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy varies widely between patients. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This approach may be particularly effective in patients with PDXs that have high levels of ROR1 expression. Thus, cirmtuzumab may be a promising therapeutic for patients with breast cancer. The timing of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. We show that the start of this event is linked to a unique series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that are similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, the high fishing pressure in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective conservation and management strategies for freshwater fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for discovering factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired. It is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing species. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions experiencing 10 times the rate of others. These regions are not uniformly distributed but are clustered into hotspots and cold regions. We also find that recombination rates peak near the start of genes and fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice with a knockout of a positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9. This suggests that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This work provides a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant and will be useful for understanding the evolution of recombination and its role in the generation of genetic diversity. Resting state networks (RSNs) are a set of anatomically contiguous brain regions that are functionally connected and show temporal correlations in the absence of task-related activity. RSNs have been identified in the human brain using functional MRI. However, the functional significance of RSNs is still unclear. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, the subordinate RSNs are associated with disease in Parkinson’s disease. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying RSN expression in healthy subjects and patients with Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease. We found that the dominant RSN was associated with reduced network expression in healthy subjects and patients with Parkinson’s disease. In contrast, the subordinate RSNs were associated with increased network expression in healthy subjects and patients with Parkinson’s disease. These results provide a direct link between RSN organization and brain function.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA is found on some mRNAs and is thought to play a role in mRNA export. Whether this modification exists in eukaryotes is unknown. We describe the discovery of 5′ NAD-RNA in yeast and show that it is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This discovery expands the number of 5′ modifications known in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that this modification could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This work also provides a model for the discovery of new RNA modifications in eukaryotes. (Show more)

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are associated with glycemia for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential epigenetic mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. This work may also have implications for the use of epigenetic modifiers in the treatment of diabetes. (Show more)

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high prevalence and a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. Moreover, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. Many of these compounds are nitrogenous, and the biosynthetic pathways for these compounds are not known. Here we report the discovery of a pathway for the biosynthesis of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is unique in plants, and the enzymes involved are distinct from those in other organisms. This pathway provides a model for the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in plants and opens the door to the development of new tomato cultivars with improved flavor. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This work highlights the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for the development of effective conservation

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. The organization of its neurons is still debated, with some studies suggesting that neurons are organized in layers, while others suggest that they are organized in clusters. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to study the organization of neurons in MEC in a natural environment. We found that neurons are organized in layers, but that they are also organized in clusters. These results have implications for our understanding of the organization of MEC and its role in spatial navigation. They also suggest that the organization of neurons in MEC is more complex than previously thought.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene in the rootless parasitic plant Cuscuta australis does not function in flowering. Instead, flowering is controlled by a mechanism that is unique to this plant. The flowering of the host plant is required for the movement of FT protein into the parasitic plant, where it physically interacts with a dodder FD transcription factor to activate flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering and the evolution of parasitism. It also provides a new model system for studying flowering and the evolution of flowering regulation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unidentified type of specialized integration unit within the dopamine-containing nigral system. These striatonigral bouquet-like formations, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites. They are connected to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Within the bouquets, many striosomal fibers are tightly intertwined with dopamine-containing dendrites and also with other types of afferents and glial cells. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets form specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This discovery may lead to new insights into the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection. But how do we know when we’ve found it? We conducted a series of experiments to explore this question. First, we showed that people can feel connected to each other based on the speed at which they respond to each other. Second, we showed that this signal is used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people. Finally, we show that this signal is robust to noise and can be used to predict the quality of a connection even when the two people are not aware of each other.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the terrestrial environment. Although its function in plant physiology has been debated for decades, recent studies have shown that Si can confer resistance to a variety of abiotic and biotic stresses. However, the role of Si in mediating plant defense responses against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against insect herbivory in rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of jasmonate (JA)-mediated defense responses. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the underlying mechanisms of the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor used in nitric oxide synthesis and aromatic amino acid hydroxylation. It is used to treat phenylketonuria. Less is known about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects the expression of genes involved in the signaling of interferon-γ and lipopolysaccharide. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also opens new perspectives for the use of tetrahydrobiopterin in the treatment of diseases related to ether lipid metabolism.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this. Here we propose a mechanism that relies on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is simple, and it is sensitive to context and serial order. It is also sensitive to the history of the system, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they rely on a variety of defense mechanisms to survive in their natural environment. One of the major defense mechanisms is the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that can damage the cell wall and cell membrane, leading to cell death. In this work, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNA to plants and silence a gene of interest. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-loaded DNA nanostructures determine the efficiency of gene silencing. Our work establishes the feasibility of using DNA nanostructures for gene silencing in plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up a new avenue for the use of DNA nanostructures in plants for the development of new crop varieties with improved resistance to environmental stresses. Nutrient pollution is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, little is known about the nutrient inputs from these small watersheds. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily nitrogen and phosphorus delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. These findings suggest that small watersheds may play a greater role in fueling coastal algal blooms than previously thought. Our results highlight the importance of small watersheds in the context of nutrient pollution and provide a framework for future efforts to address nutrient pollution in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare configurations of the environment. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can be explained by a dynamic causal model of the microcircuitry. Finally, we show that the same changes in the microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities when the brain is pushed beyond its tolerance limits. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same mechanisms may be responsible for the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in other autoimmune encephalitis. This may lead to a better understanding of the pathophysiology of these disorders and the development of more effective treatments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key topic in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and widespread seafloor anoxia. These results highlight the importance of organic matter in the Earth system and the potential for organic matter-driven climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to the protection of remaining forests. These findings are important for the future of certification in the palm oil sector.

The exocytosis process is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In other vertebrates, multiple genetic loci interact to determine sex. In this paper, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination loci in a fish species.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that relies on Fe for redox active energy and electron transfer. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe plays a role in the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly, and other retinal disorders. Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, can evolve specialization on different prey types, and that these transitions are linked to the evolution of their specialized structures. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. The earliest hominins are known from 800,000-year-old deposits, but the evolution of the hand is poorly understood before 1.8 My. We report the discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 My ago. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways supporting cell growth is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway. This pathway is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is a promising target for cancer therapy, but its inhibition is associated with adverse effects. Here we identify a scaffold that inhibits SHMT, and we use this scaffold to discover dual inhibitors of SHMT1/2. We show that these inhibitors are effective in cancer cells, but not in normal cells. We also show that one of the adverse effects of SHMT inhibition is defective glycine import into cancer cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets as well as their conservation and environmental benefits.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of increased subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in compaction risk has been so severe that it has now reached a critical threshold for ecological functioning. We propose that the roaming of sauropods, the largest terrestrial animals to have walked Earth, may have been a strategy for reducing subsoil compaction.
